topic: Advent of Europeans and Consolidation of British Power

flashcards.front: Papal Authority for Portuguese exploration?
flashcards.back: 1454: Pope Nicholas V granted Prince Henry of Portugal the right to explore the East, including India

flashcards.front: Treaty of Tordesillas (1494)? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Agreement between Portugal and Spain dividing non-Christian world by imaginary line in Atlantic.

flashcards.front: Treaty of Tordesillas (1494)? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Portugal got territories east of line, including India

flashcards.front: Who rounded Cape of Good Hope and when?
flashcards.back: Bartholomeu Dias in 1487, opening maritime route to Indian Ocean

flashcards.front: Vasco da Gama's arrival in India?
flashcards.back: 1498 - first European to reach India by sea, landed at Calicut

flashcards.front: Who guided Vasco da Gama to India?
flashcards.back: Abdul Majid, a Gujarati pilot

flashcards.front: Vasco da Gama's three visits to India?
flashcards.back: 1498 (discovery), 1501 (established factory at Cannanore), 1524 (died in Cochin)

flashcards.front: Pedro Alvarez Cabral's year and action?
flashcards.back: 1500 - set up factory at Calicut, retaliated against attack by seizing Arab ships and bombarding Calicut

flashcards.front: Francisco de Almeida's governorship?
flashcards.back: 1505 - First Governor of Portuguese India, implemented Blue Water Policy

flashcards.front: Battle of Diu (1507)?
flashcards.back: Almeida's fleet defeated by Zamorin and Mamluk Sultan of Egypt near Diu; his son died in battle

flashcards.front: Almeida's revenge (1508)?
flashcards.back: Crushed combined Egyptian and Gujarat forces after 1507 defeat

flashcards.front: Afonso de Albuquerque's governorship?
flashcards.back: 1509 - Considered real founder of Portuguese power in the East

flashcards.front: Portuguese acquisition of Goa?
flashcards.back: 1510 - Albuquerque captured from Sultan of Bijapur; first Indian territory under European control since Alexander [UPSC 2022]

flashcards.front: Nino da Cunha's key action?
flashcards.back: Moved Portuguese capital from Cochin to Goa in 1530

flashcards.front: Bahadur Shah and Portuguese?
flashcards.back: 1534 - Gujarat Sultan ceded Bassein and promised Diu for support against Humayun; killed by Portuguese in 1537 during negotiations

flashcards.front: First European fort in India?
flashcards.back: Fort Emmanuel at Cochin, built 1503 - 137 years before any British fortification

flashcards.front: Krishnadevaraya & Portuguese?
flashcards.back: Medieval Vijayanagara ruler gave Portuguese permission to build fort at Bhatkal [UPSC 2024]

flashcards.front: Crops introduced by Portuguese (UPSC 2025)?
flashcards.back: Papaya, Pineapple, and Guava in 16th-17th centuries

flashcards.front: Other crops introduced by Albuquerque?
flashcards.back: Tobacco and Cashew

flashcards.front: Portuguese Hooghly base?
flashcards.back: Established in Bengal in 16th century; captured by Mughals in 1632 after siege under Shah Jahan

flashcards.front: Portuguese territories in India?
flashcards.back: Goa (capital), Mumbai, Daman & Diu, trading posts at Mangalore, Calicut, Cannanore, Cochin, San Thome (Chennai), Nagapattinam

flashcards.front: Jesuits to Mughal court?
flashcards.back: 1580 - sent to Akbar's court; attempts to convert him failed

flashcards.front: Portuguese-Mughal relations timeline?
flashcards.back: Good under Akbar & Jahangir; deteriorated after British entry (1608); lost favour under Shah Jahan

flashcards.front: When did Portuguese leave India?
flashcards.back: 1961 - after 463 years, when Goa was liberated by Indian forces

flashcards.front: Capital shifts?
flashcards.back: Cochin (initial) → Goa (1530 under Nino da Cunha)

flashcards.front: Portuguese main trading period?
flashcards.back: 1498-1663 (dominance); declined after Dutch/English competition

flashcards.front: Why did Pope grant Portugal exploration rights? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Catholic Church wanted to spread Christianity to the East and counter Islamic expansion.

flashcards.front: Why did Pope grant Portugal exploration rights? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Portugal was leading maritime nation willing to undertake missions. Papal bull legitimized Portuguese monopoly over Eastern trade routes

flashcards.front: Significance of Treaty of Tordesillas for India? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Gave Portugal legal/religious justification for Eastern expansion without Spanish competition.

flashcards.front: Significance of Treaty of Tordesillas for India? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Allowed focused investment in Indian Ocean trade without European rivalry initially. Spain focused on Americas, Portugal on Asia

flashcards.front: What was the Blue Water Policy (Cartaze)? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Naval policy by Almeida to fortify/control Indian Ocean for Portuguese business monopoly, not security.

flashcards.front: What was the Blue Water Policy (Cartaze)? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Required all ships to obtain Portuguese cartaz (license/permit) to trade, backed by naval force.

flashcards.front: What was the Blue Water Policy (Cartaze)? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Created protection racket extracting fees from Asian traders

flashcards.front: Why was Goa chosen as capital over Cochin? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Strategic location on western coast with excellent harbor.

flashcards.front: Why was Goa chosen as capital over Cochin? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Centrally positioned between northern (Gujarat) and southern (Kerala) trading zones. Better defense potential.

flashcards.front: Why was Goa chosen as capital over Cochin? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Could project power across Arabian Sea

flashcards.front: Why did Albuquerque encourage intermarriage? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Too few Portuguese settlers to maintain control. Intermarriage created mixed-race population (mestiços) loyal to Portugal.

flashcards.front: Why did Albuquerque encourage intermarriage? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Helped cultural integration and reduced resistance. Built permanent Portuguese community in India

flashcards.front: Why did Albuquerque abolish sati? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Part of civilizing mission justifying Portuguese presence. Gained Hindu support against Islamic rulers.

flashcards.front: Why did Albuquerque abolish sati? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Demonstrated Portuguese authority over local customs. Enhanced moral legitimacy for colonial project

flashcards.front: What made Vasco da Gama's voyage groundbreaking? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: First all-sea route from Europe to India, bypassing overland routes. Broke Arab-Venetian monopoly on spice trade.

flashcards.front: What made Vasco da Gama's voyage groundbreaking? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Reduced transport costs dramatically. Opened age of European colonialism in Asia

flashcards.front: Why did Cabral resort to violence at Calicut? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Portuguese factory attacked, showing local resistance.

flashcards.front: Why did Cabral resort to violence at Calicut? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Cabral used overwhelming force (seizing ships, bombardment) to establish terror and respect.

flashcards.front: Why did Cabral resort to violence at Calicut? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Set pattern of Portuguese using brutal tactics to enforce monopoly

flashcards.front: Almeida's strategic vision for Indian Ocean? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Naval dominance over trade routes rather than territorial control. Control chokepoints (Aden, Ormuz, Malacca).

flashcards.front: Almeida's strategic vision for Indian Ocean? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Force all traders to pay tribute/license fees. Maintain mobile fleet, not costly land armies

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese face Zamorin's resistance? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Calicut Zamorin had profitable arrangement with Arab traders. Portuguese monopoly threatened his revenue.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese face Zamorin's resistance? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Religious differences (Hindu ruler vs. Catholic Portuguese). Portuguese demanded exclusive trading rights, unacceptable to Zamorin

flashcards.front: Significance of Albuquerque as 'real founder'? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Almeida focused on naval control; Albuquerque added territorial bases. Captured Goa (first territory), establishing permanent foothold.

flashcards.front: Significance of Albuquerque as 'real founder'? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Expanded to Ormuz, Malacca - strategic bases securing trade routes. Combined naval + territorial strategy

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese-Mughal relations deteriorate? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Portuguese piracy in Arabian Sea angered Mughals. Competition with English after 1608 reduced Portuguese importance.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese-Mughal relations deteriorate? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Portuguese religious intolerance clashed with Mughal pluralism. Hooghly became pirate base raiding Mughal ships

flashcards.front: Why siege of Hooghly 1632? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Portuguese engaged in slave trade and piracy from Hooghly. Mughal ships attacked in Bay of Bengal. Shah Jahan wanted to assert sovereignty.

flashcards.front: Why siege of Hooghly 1632? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Portuguese refused to acknowledge Mughal authority. Siege punished piracy and established Mughal control

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious policy motivations? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Catholic Church mandate to spread Christianity. Counter Reformation zeal against Protestants and non-Christians.

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious policy motivations? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Justify colonialism as civilizing mission. Inquisition in Goa (1560) enforced conversions.

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious policy motivations? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Initially tolerated Hindus but later forcibly converted

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese introduce new crops? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Tobacco and cashew were profitable cash crops. Papaya, pineapple, guava enriched diet and could be traded.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese introduce new crops? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Agricultural diversification beyond spices. Created economic ties between Portugal and India

flashcards.front: What was Estado da Índia? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Portuguese colonial administration governing all Asian territories from East Africa to Japan. Headquartered in Goa.

flashcards.front: What was Estado da Índia? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Viceroy/Governor reported to Lisbon. Combined commercial monopoly with territorial governance

flashcards.front: Why did Bahadur Shah seek Portuguese help? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Faced Humayun's invasion of Gujarat (1534). Needed Portuguese naval/military support.

flashcards.front: Why did Bahadur Shah seek Portuguese help? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Offered territorial concessions (Bassein, Diu) in exchange. Portuguese happy to gain bases while Gujarat got protection

flashcards.front: Why was Bahadur Shah killed by Portuguese? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Relations soured after Humayun withdrew - Bahadur Shah felt Portuguese demands excessive. Portuguese suspected double-dealing.

flashcards.front: Why was Bahadur Shah killed by Portuguese? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: During negotiations (1537), Portuguese killed him - likely planned assassination to seize Diu forcibly

flashcards.front: Portuguese settlement strategy? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Establish fortified coastal bases, not inland expansion. Control maritime trade, not territory.

flashcards.front: Portuguese settlement strategy? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Create settler communities through intermarriage. Maintain naval superiority. Avoid costly land wars with Indian powers

flashcards.front: Impact of Portuguese on Indian Ocean trade? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Broke Arab monopoly on spice trade to Europe. Introduced European-style fortified trading posts.

flashcards.front: Impact of Portuguese on Indian Ocean trade? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Violent enforcement of trade monopolies disrupted centuries-old Asian trading networks. Began European dominance ending only in 20th century

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese decline after 1600? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Spanish union (1580-1640) diverted resources. Dutch and English maritime powers challenged monopoly. Overextended across Africa-Asia.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese decline after 1600? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Corrupt administration. Focus shifted to Brazil. Lost key bases to Dutch (Malacca 1641, Cochin 1663)

flashcards.front: Portuguese vs. Arab traders conflict? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Arabs controlled spice trade for centuries via Red Sea route. Portuguese wanted direct access to cut out middlemen.

flashcards.front: Portuguese vs. Arab traders conflict? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Religious animosity (Christian vs. Muslim). Portuguese used superior naval technology to forcibly replace Arab dominance

flashcards.front: Role of Gujarati pilots for Portuguese? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Local navigational expertise crucial - Abdul Majid guided Vasco da Gama. Portuguese lacked knowledge of monsoon winds, coastal waters.

flashcards.front: Role of Gujarati pilots for Portuguese? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Indian pilots became essential for Portuguese navigation. Shows Portuguese dependence on local collaboration

flashcards.front: Why Fort Emmanuel was significant? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: First permanent European military structure in India (1503). Marked shift from temporary trading posts to fortified settlements.

flashcards.front: Why Fort Emmanuel was significant? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Became model for later European forts. Symbolized beginning of European colonial military presence

flashcards.front: Permit system for other ships? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: All vessels needed Portuguese cartaz to trade in Indian Ocean. Fees generated huge revenue. Enforced by Portuguese naval patrols.

flashcards.front: Permit system for other ships? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Ships without permits were attacked/confiscated. Created protection racket monopoly

flashcards.front: Almeida vs. Albuquerque strategy? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Almeida: Naval control only ('Blue Water Policy'), mobile fleet, no territorial ambitions.

flashcards.front: Almeida vs. Albuquerque strategy? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Albuquerque: Naval + territorial, captured bases (Goa, Ormuz, Malacca), permanent settlements.

flashcards.front: Almeida vs. Albuquerque strategy? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Albuquerque's approach proved more effective for long-term control

flashcards.front: Portuguese vs. Arab traders in Indian Ocean? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Arabs: Centuries-old networks, trade through persuasion, integrated with local rulers.

flashcards.front: Portuguese vs. Arab traders in Indian Ocean? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Portuguese: Military force, monopoly through violence, fortified bases, religious hostility.

flashcards.front: Portuguese vs. Arab traders in Indian Ocean? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Portuguese superior naval technology defeated Arab dhows

flashcards.front: Vasco da Gama's first (1498) vs. second (1501) voyage? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: First: Exploratory, friendly reception from Zamorin, establishing contact.

flashcards.front: Vasco da Gama's first (1498) vs. second (1501) voyage? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Second: Commercial, established factory at Cannanore, more aggressive stance. Third (1524): As Viceroy, died shortly after arrival.

flashcards.front: Vasco da Gama's first (1498) vs. second (1501) voyage? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Progressively more assertive Portuguese presence

flashcards.front: Cochin vs. Goa as capital? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Cochin: Initial base (1503-1530), southern location, limited hinterland.

flashcards.front: Cochin vs. Goa as capital? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Goa: Central west coast, better harbor, more defensible, access to both north and south, greater strategic value.

flashcards.front: Cochin vs. Goa as capital? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Move to Goa showed Portuguese consolidating power

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious policy: Muslims vs. Hindus? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Muslims: Immediate persecution, trade competition, religious hostility.

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious policy: Muslims vs. Hindus? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Hindus: Initially tolerated (majority population, no trade rivalry), later persecuted for conversions.

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious policy: Muslims vs. Hindus? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Shows Portuguese prioritized eliminating Muslim trade competition

flashcards.front: Albuquerque's Goa acquisition vs. Nino da Cunha's Gujarat gains? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Goa (1510): Military conquest from Bijapur, permanent territorial control, became capital.

flashcards.front: Albuquerque's Goa acquisition vs. Nino da Cunha's Gujarat gains? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Gujarat (1534): Diplomatic concession from Bahadur Shah, but relations broke down, Bahadur killed (1537).

flashcards.front: Albuquerque's Goa acquisition vs. Nino da Cunha's Gujarat gains? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Conquest more stable than negotiated cessions

flashcards.front: Portuguese India vs. Portuguese Brazil? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: India: Trade-focused, coastal bases, limited settlement. Brazil: Plantation colonies, large-scale settlement, territorial expansion.

flashcards.front: Portuguese India vs. Portuguese Brazil? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: After 1600, Portugal prioritized Brazil over India due to sugar wealth and less military resistance

flashcards.front: Portuguese Hooghly vs. Goa? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Goa: Official capital, administrative center, fortified, permanent settlement, legal trade.

flashcards.front: Portuguese Hooghly vs. Goa? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Hooghly: Trading post, semi-autonomous, engaged in piracy/slavery, captured by Mughals (1632).

flashcards.front: Portuguese Hooghly vs. Goa? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Shows Portuguese couldn't control distant outposts

flashcards.front: Blue Water Policy vs. Territorial Control? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Blue Water: Control sea lanes, mobile fleet, protection fees, lower costs.

flashcards.front: Blue Water Policy vs. Territorial Control? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Territorial: Permanent bases, expensive garrisons, administrative costs, long-term security.

flashcards.front: Blue Water Policy vs. Territorial Control? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Portuguese needed both: fleet for dominance, bases for logistics

flashcards.front: Portuguese trade pattern: pre-1600 vs. post-1600? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Pre-1600: Monopoly on spice trade, minimal European competition, Arab competitors defeated.

flashcards.front: Portuguese trade pattern: pre-1600 vs. post-1600? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Post-1600: Dutch and English entry broke monopoly, loss of key bases, decline in profits, focus shifted to Brazil. Peak to decline

flashcards.front: Cartaz system vs. traditional Asian trade? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Traditional: Open access, local rulers tax trade, multiple ports competing.

flashcards.front: Cartaz system vs. traditional Asian trade? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Cartaz: Portuguese license required, enforced by violence, monopoly control, high fees. Revolutionary but unpopular - imposed by force

flashcards.front: Portuguese in India vs. Spanish in Americas? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: India: Trading posts, naval dominance, existing kingdoms not conquered.

flashcards.front: Portuguese in India vs. Spanish in Americas? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Americas: Territorial conquest, destroyed indigenous empires, settlement colonies.

flashcards.front: Portuguese in India vs. Spanish in Americas? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Treaty of Tordesillas divided spheres, different opportunities dictated different strategies

flashcards.front: Fort Emmanuel (1503) vs. Fort St. George (English, 1640)? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Fort Emmanuel: First European fort in India, 137 years earlier, Portuguese maritime dominance era. Fort St.

flashcards.front: Fort Emmanuel (1503) vs. Fort St. George (English, 1640)? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: George: English entry when Portuguese declining, became Madras Presidency.

flashcards.front: Fort Emmanuel (1503) vs. Fort St. George (English, 1640)? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Shows Portuguese pioneered fortification strategy copied by later Europeans

flashcards.front: Almeida's 1507 defeat vs. 1508 victory? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: 1507 near Diu: Portuguese fleet defeated by Zamorin-Mamluk alliance, Almeida's son killed, showed Portuguese vulnerability.

flashcards.front: Almeida's 1507 defeat vs. 1508 victory? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: 1508: Almeida's revenge crushed combined forces, reasserted Portuguese dominance. Demonstrated importance of Portuguese naval superiority

flashcards.front: Portuguese-Mughal relations: Akbar vs. Shah Jahan? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Akbar (1556-1605): Friendly, received Jesuits (1580), tolerated Portuguese traders.

flashcards.front: Portuguese-Mughal relations: Akbar vs. Shah Jahan? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Shah Jahan (1628-1658): Hostile, besieged Hooghly (1632), punished piracy.

flashcards.front: Portuguese-Mughal relations: Akbar vs. Shah Jahan? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Shows deterioration due to Portuguese piracy and English alternative

flashcards.front: Cabral's factory violence vs. later Portuguese strategy? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Cabral (1500): Immediate violent retaliation when factory attacked - seizing ships, bombardment, establishing fear.

flashcards.front: Cabral's factory violence vs. later Portuguese strategy? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Later strategy: Systematic control through Cartaz, permanent forts, intermarriage. Evolved from reactive violence to institutional control

flashcards.front: Portuguese crops (tobacco, cashew) vs. English crops (tea, coffee)? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Portuguese: Introduced 16th century, integrated locally, enriched diet/economy.

flashcards.front: Portuguese crops (tobacco, cashew) vs. English crops (tea, coffee)? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: English: 18th-19th century, plantation-based, monoculture, forced commercialization.

flashcards.front: Portuguese crops (tobacco, cashew) vs. English crops (tea, coffee)? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Portuguese contribution more benign, English more exploitative

flashcards.front: Krishnadevaraya's Portuguese relations vs. Bahadur Shah's? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Krishnadevaraya (Vijayanagara): Allowed Bhatkal fort [UPSC 2024], cooperative, non-threatening.

flashcards.front: Krishnadevaraya's Portuguese relations vs. Bahadur Shah's? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Bahadur Shah (Gujarat): Sought help against Humayun, ceded territories, killed in double-cross.

flashcards.front: Krishnadevaraya's Portuguese relations vs. Bahadur Shah's? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Shows Portuguese opportunism - cooperate or conquer as suits them

flashcards.front: Portuguese Jesuits vs. English missionaries? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Portuguese Jesuits: Arrived 1580, focused on Mughal court elite, failed to convert Akbar.

flashcards.front: Portuguese Jesuits vs. English missionaries? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: English missionaries: 19th century, focused on lower classes, social reforms. Portuguese religious agenda earlier but less successful

flashcards.front: Portuguese decline reasons vs. Arab decline reasons? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Arabs: Defeated militarily by Portuguese superior naval technology, lost monopoly forcibly.

flashcards.front: Portuguese decline reasons vs. Arab decline reasons? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Portuguese: Challenged by Dutch/English, overextension, Spanish union, administrative corruption.

flashcards.front: Portuguese decline reasons vs. Arab decline reasons? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Technology defeated Arabs; competition and decline defeated Portuguese

flashcards.front: Why was Portuguese Indian Ocean strategy revolutionary? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: First European power to use naval force to monopolize Asian trade. Combined military technology (cannons, ships) with permit system.

flashcards.front: Why was Portuguese Indian Ocean strategy revolutionary? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Created protection racket extracting wealth without territorial conquest initially. Blueprint for later European maritime empires

flashcards.front: Goa's strategic importance for Portuguese empire? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Central west coast position controlled Arabian Sea trade. Deep water harbor for large ships.

flashcards.front: Goa's strategic importance for Portuguese empire? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Access to both Malabar (south) and Gujarat (north). Base for projecting power to Ormuz (Persian Gulf), Malacca (Southeast Asia).

flashcards.front: Goa's strategic importance for Portuguese empire? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Administrative capital coordinating Asian operations

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese prioritize controlling chokepoints? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Aden (Red Sea entrance), Ormuz (Persian Gulf), Malacca (to China/spice islands) were trade route bottlenecks.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese prioritize controlling chokepoints? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Controlling these meant controlling all maritime trade. Cheaper than conquering territories. Could levy fees/taxes on all passing ships

flashcards.front: Portuguese settler policy implications? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Encouraged intermarriage creating mestiço community loyal to Portugal. Given land grants making them stakeholders.

flashcards.front: Portuguese settler policy implications? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Too few pure Portuguese to maintain control. Created permanent Portuguese-Indian hybrid culture in Goa lasting centuries

flashcards.front: Economic impact of Portuguese monopoly on Indian traders? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Disrupted traditional Asian trading networks that operated for centuries. Forced Indian/Arab merchants to buy costly Portuguese permits.

flashcards.front: Economic impact of Portuguese monopoly on Indian traders? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Raised prices, reduced merchant profits. Some Indian ports declined as Portuguese diverted trade to their bases

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese fail to expand inland? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Naval power useless on land. Indian kingdoms too strong for small Portuguese forces.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese fail to expand inland? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: No economic incentive - profits came from maritime trade, not land revenue.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese fail to expand inland? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Focused resources on controlling sea routes, not conquering territories

flashcards.front: Role of cartaz system in Portuguese wealth? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Every ship needed license - generated massive fee income. Enforced by naval patrols capturing/sinking violators.

flashcards.front: Role of cartaz system in Portuguese wealth? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Non-compliance meant cargo confiscation. Created steady revenue stream from Asian maritime trade without territorial costs

flashcards.front: Why did Mughal-Portuguese conflict at Hooghly matter? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Showed limits of Portuguese power against major Indian empires. Mughals could crush Portuguese bases when determined.

flashcards.front: Why did Mughal-Portuguese conflict at Hooghly matter? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Portuguese piracy threatened Mughal sovereignty and trade. 1632 siege ended Portuguese Bengal presence, confined them to coastal enclaves

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious zeal vs. commercial interests? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Catholic mission to convert clashed with profit motive. Persecution of Muslims reduced trade with Islamic networks.

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious zeal vs. commercial interests? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Forced conversions alienated Hindu populations. Goa Inquisition (1560) harmed reputation.

flashcards.front: Portuguese religious zeal vs. commercial interests? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Religious extremism ultimately hurt commercial goals

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese survive 463 years in India? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Focused on defensible coastal enclaves, not vulnerable interior. Avoided challenging major powers directly.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese survive 463 years in India? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Intermarriage created local roots. When declining, held onto Goa due to minimal threat to British/post-independence India.

flashcards.front: Why did Portuguese survive 463 years in India? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Cultural integration enabled survival

flashcards.front: Portuguese vulnerability in extended trade network? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Overextended from Mozambique to Japan. Each base needed garrisons, supplies, defense. Communication slow (months between Goa-Lisbon).

flashcards.front: Portuguese vulnerability in extended trade network? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Difficult to coordinate defense against multiple threats (Dutch, English). Scattered bases easier to pick off

flashcards.front: Impact of Spanish union (1580-1640) on Portuguese India? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Spain prioritized Americas over Asia. Portuguese resources diverted to Spanish wars.

flashcards.front: Impact of Spanish union (1580-1640) on Portuguese India? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Dutch (fighting Spanish independence) attacked Portuguese bases. Union weakened Portuguese focus on Indian Ocean.

flashcards.front: Impact of Spanish union (1580-1640) on Portuguese India? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Lost key bases during this period

flashcards.front: Why introduce new crops? (Part 1/2)
flashcards.back: Diversified economy beyond spices. Created agricultural ties binding communities. Tobacco lucrative cash crop.

flashcards.front: Why introduce new crops? (Part 2/2)
flashcards.back: Food crops (papaya, guava) improved nutrition. Economic development justified colonial presence, benefited Portugal and India

flashcards.front: Portuguese administrative structure weakness? (Part 1/3)
flashcards.back: Estado da Índia covered too vast area (Africa to Japan). Governor/Viceroy in Goa couldn't effectively supervise distant posts.

flashcards.front: Portuguese administrative structure weakness? (Part 2/3)
flashcards.back: Corruption widespread due to poor oversight. Officials often pursued private profit over Crown interests.

flashcards.front: Portuguese administrative structure weakness? (Part 3/3)
flashcards.back: Weak central control enabled abuses

flashcards.front: Long-term legacy of Portuguese in India? (Part 1/4)
flashcards.back: Broke Arab monopoly permanently. Introduced European-style fortified trading system.

flashcards.front: Long-term legacy of Portuguese in India? (Part 2/4)

mcq.question: Which Pope granted Portugal the right to explore the East in 1454?
mcq.explanation: Pope Nicholas V granted Prince Henry of Portugal the right to explore the East, including India, in 1454, providing religious sanction for Portuguese expansion.

mcq.question: Who guided Vasco da Gama from East Africa to Calicut in 1498?
mcq.explanation: Abdul Majid, a Gujarati pilot, guided Vasco da Gama across the Indian Ocean to Calicut, demonstrating Portuguese reliance on local navigational expertise.

mcq.question: In which year did Afonso de Albuquerque capture Goa? [UPSC 2022 context]
mcq.explanation: Albuquerque captured Goa from the Sultan of Bijapur in 1510, making it the first Indian territory under European control since Alexander the Great [UPSC 2022].

mcq.question: The 'Blue Water Policy' was implemented by which Portuguese Governor?
mcq.explanation: Francisco de Almeida implemented the Blue Water Policy (Cartaze system) to control the Indian Ocean through naval dominance and a licensing system for ships.

mcq.question: Which crops were introduced to India by the Portuguese in the 16th-17th centuries? [UPSC 2025]
mcq.explanation: Papaya, Pineapple, and Guava were introduced to India by the Portuguese in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries [UPSC 2025].

mcq.question: Which medieval ruler gave Portuguese permission to build a fort at Bhatkal? [UPSC 2024]
mcq.explanation: Krishnadevaraya of Vijayanagara gave Portuguese permission to build a fort at Bhatkal [UPSC 2024], showing cooperative relations with strong Indian kingdoms.

mcq.question: In which year did the Mughals capture Portuguese Hooghly after a siege?
mcq.explanation: Under Shah Jahan, the Mughals besieged and captured Portuguese Hooghly in 1632, ending Portuguese presence in Bengal due to piracy and slave trading.

mcq.question: What was the first European fort built in India?
mcq.explanation: Fort Emmanuel at Cochin, built by Portuguese in 1503, was the first European fort in India—137 years before any British fortification.

mcq.question: Who is considered the 'real founder' of Portuguese power in the East?
mcq.explanation: Afonso de Albuquerque is considered the real founder of Portuguese power as he captured territorial bases (Goa, Ormuz, Malacca) and established lasting administrative systems.

mcq.question: In which year did Nino da Cunha move the Portuguese capital from Cochin to Goa?
mcq.explanation: Nino da Cunha moved the Portuguese capital from Cochin to Goa in 1530, centralizing Portuguese administration in a more strategic location.

mcq.question: What was the Treaty of Tordesillas (1494)?
options: Treaty between Portugal and England dividing Asian trade
Agreement between Portugal and Spain dividing non-Christian world
Peace treaty between Portugal and Zamorin
mcq.explanation: Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) divided the non-Christian world between Portugal and Spain by an imaginary line in the Atlantic. Portugal gained rights over territories east of this line, including India.

mcq.question: Who was the first Portuguese Governor of India (1505)?
mcq.explanation: Francisco de Almeida was appointed the first Governor of Portuguese India in 1505, tasked with consolidating Portuguese power by disrupting Muslim trade.

mcq.question: In which battle (1507) was Francisco de Almeida's fleet defeated?
mcq.explanation: In 1507, Almeida's fleet was defeated near Diu by the combined forces of the Zamorin and Mamluk Sultan of Egypt. Almeida's son died in this battle.

mcq.question: What social reform did Albuquerque introduce in Portuguese territories?
mcq.explanation: Afonso de Albuquerque abolished sati in Portuguese territories, introduced new crops, and encouraged intermarriage between Portuguese settlers and local populations.

mcq.question: Which Portuguese Governor moved the capital from Cochin to Goa in 1530?
mcq.explanation: Nino da Cunha became Governor in 1529 and moved the Portuguese capital from Cochin to Goa in 1530, centralizing Portuguese administration.

mcq.question: Which ruler of Gujarat was killed by the Portuguese in 1537 during negotiations?
mcq.explanation: Bahadur Shah of Gujarat, who had ceded Bassein and promised Diu to the Portuguese, was killed by them in 1537 during negotiations after relations soured.

mcq.question: What was the Cartaz system?
options: Licensing system for ships to control Indian Ocean trade
mcq.explanation: The Cartaz system was a licensing system requiring all ships to obtain Portuguese permits to trade in the Indian Ocean, enforced through naval patrols.

mcq.question: Which Portuguese base in Bengal was captured by Mughals in 1632?
mcq.explanation: Under Shah Jahan, the Mughals besieged and captured Portuguese Hooghly in 1632, ending Portuguese presence in Bengal due to piracy and slave trading activities.

mcq.question: When did Jesuits first visit the Mughal court?
mcq.explanation: Portuguese Jesuits were sent to the Mughal court in 1580 during Akbar's reign. Despite multiple missions, attempts to convert Akbar to Christianity failed.

mcq.question: Which crops did Albuquerque introduce to India?
mcq.explanation: Afonso de Albuquerque introduced tobacco and cashew to India. These became important crops in Portuguese territories and spread throughout India.

mcq.question: What was the 'Blue Water Policy'?
options: Policy to promote maritime trade education
Naval fortification of Indian Ocean for Portuguese business monopoly
mcq.explanation: The Blue Water Policy, implemented by Almeida, focused on fortification of the Indian Ocean not for security but for establishing Portuguese business monopoly through naval dominance.

mcq.question: Who retaliated in 1508 after his son's death in the 1507 Battle of Diu?
mcq.explanation: Francisco de Almeida retaliated in 1508, crushing the combined Egyptian and Gujarat forces after his fleet's defeat and his son's death near Diu in 1507.

mcq.question: Which Portuguese territories in India were controlled until 1961?
mcq.explanation: Portugal controlled Goa, Daman, and Diu until 1961, when they were liberated and integrated into India after 463 years of Portuguese presence.

mcq.question: What policy did Albuquerque encourage to create a loyal Portuguese-Indian community?
options: Intermarriage between Portuguese settlers and locals
mcq.explanation: Albuquerque encouraged intermarriage between Portuguese settlers and local populations, creating a mixed mestiço community loyal to Portugal with permanent roots in India.

mcq.question: Why did Portuguese-Mughal relations deteriorate under Shah Jahan?
options: Portuguese piracy and slave trading from Hooghly
mcq.explanation: Portuguese engaged in piracy against Mughal ships and slave trading from Hooghly base, angering the Mughal government and leading to the siege and capture of Hooghly in 1632.

comprehensive.question: Analyze the evolution of Portuguese strategy in India from Vasco da Gama (1498) to Albuquerque (1510). How did Portuguese approach shift from exploration to territorial control?
comprehensive.answer: Portuguese strategy evolved in three phases: 1) Exploration (1498-1500): Vasco da Gama established contact, friendly reception from Zamorin, focused on trade possibilities.

comprehensive.question: Compare and contrast the strategies of Francisco de Almeida and Afonso de Albuquerque. Why is Albuquerque considered the 'real founder' despite Almeida arriving first?
comprehensive.answer: Almeida (1505-1509): Focused exclusively on naval control ('Blue Water Policy'). Believed mobile fleet controlling sea lanes was sufficient. Implemented Cartaz licensing system. Avoided territorial commitments. Strategy was cost-effective but lacked permanence.

comprehensive.question: Examine the Cartaz (permit) system. How did it function as both an economic tool and instrument of Portuguese maritime dominance? What were its impacts on traditional Asian trade networks?
comprehensive.answer: Cartaz System: Portuguese-issued licenses required for all ships trading in Indian Ocean. Ships without permits were attacked, cargo confiscated. Enforced by Portuguese naval patrols. As Economic Tool: Generated massive revenue from licensing fees without territorial costs.

comprehensive.question: Analyze Portuguese-Mughal relations from Akbar to Shah Jahan. What factors caused the deterioration from cooperation to conflict?
comprehensive.answer: Akbar Era (1556-1605): Positive relations. Akbar received Portuguese Jesuits (1580) at court, though conversion attempts failed. Portuguese allowed to trade freely. Mutual benefits - Portugal needed Mughal goodwill for inland trade; Mughals valued Portuguese naval power and European goods.

comprehensive.question: Evaluate the long-term impact of Portuguese presence in India (1498-1961). Beyond trade, what cultural, agricultural, and strategic legacies did they leave?
comprehensive.answer: Cultural Legacy: Indo-Portuguese community in Goa with distinct architecture (churches, houses), cuisine (vindaloo, bebinca), language (Portuguese-influenced Konkani). Catholic Christianity established, lasting to present. Intermarriage created mestizo population bridging cultures.

comprehensive.question: Why did Portuguese choose Goa as their capital instead of earlier bases like Calicut or Cochin? Analyze the strategic, economic, and political factors.
comprehensive.answer: Strategic Factors: Central west coast location between northern (Gujarat) and southern (Malabar) trading zones. Excellent natural deep-water harbor suitable for large Portuguese carracks. More defensible than Cochin - surrounded by water on three sides, easier to fortify.

comprehensive.question: Examine the relationship between Bahadur Shah of Gujarat and the Portuguese (1534-1537). What does this episode reveal about Portuguese diplomatic-military tactics?
comprehensive.answer: Background (1534): Humayun invaded Gujarat, threatening Bahadur Shah's rule. Desperate, Bahadur sought Portuguese naval support. Portuguese Terms: In exchange for military help, Bahadur ceded Bassein (1534) and promised Diu - key Gujarat ports.

comprehensive.question: Why did the Portuguese introduce new crops (tobacco, cashew, papaya, pineapple, guava) to India? Analyze the economic and strategic motivations.
comprehensive.answer: Economic Motivations: Tobacco: Highly profitable cash crop with European demand. Cultivation enriched Portuguese territories and traders. Became major export. Cashew: Native to Brazil, Portuguese monopoly initially. Valuable nut and processing byproducts. Goa became cashew processing center.

comprehensive.question: Analyze the significance of Fort Emmanuel (Cochin, 1503) as the first European fortification in India. How did this mark a shift in European-Asian relations?
comprehensive.answer: Historical Context: Built 1503, just 5 years after Vasco da Gama's arrival. 137 years before first British fort (Fort St. George, 1640). Marked shift from temporary trading factories to permanent military structures.

comprehensive.question: Why did Portuguese power decline after 1600, losing most territories except Goa? Identify and analyze the key factors in their decline.
comprehensive.answer: External Factors: Dutch/English Competition: Dutch (1602) and English (1600) East India Companies challenged Portuguese monopoly. Superior organization, more capital, better ships. Dutch specifically targeted Portuguese possessions (Malacca 1641, Cochin 1663, Ceylon).

comprehensive.question: Analyze the significance of the Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) for Portuguese expansion into India. How did papal authority legitimize European colonialism?
comprehensive.answer: The Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) divided the non-Christian world between Portugal and Spain by an imaginary line in the Atlantic Ocean. Portugal gained exclusive rights over territories east of the line, including India and the Indian Ocean.

comprehensive.question: Compare Francisco de Almeida's defeat at Diu (1507) with his revenge in 1508. What does this tell us about Portuguese naval power and vulnerability?
comprehensive.answer: The 1507 defeat near Diu revealed Portuguese vulnerability: Combined Zamorin-Mamluk Egyptian fleet defeated Almeida's forces, killing his son. This showed: 1) Portuguese weren't invincible, 2) Asian powers could challenge them when united, 3) Overconfidence was dangerous.

comprehensive.question: Evaluate Albuquerque's policy of encouraging intermarriage between Portuguese settlers and local populations. What were the strategic, demographic, and cultural implications?
comprehensive.answer: Strategic Implications: Too few Portuguese could settle India permanently. Intermarriage created mixed-race mestiço population with stake in Portuguese rule. These communities became intermediaries, administrators, soldiers - essential for governance with minimal European presence.

comprehensive.question: Examine the evolution of Portuguese religious policy in India from initial tolerance of Hindus to later persecution. What drove this shift and what were its consequences?
comprehensive.answer: Initial Tolerance (1500-1540): Early Portuguese focused on eliminating Muslim trade competition - primary commercial rivals. Hindus weren't trade threat and comprised majority population. Pragmatism dictated tolerance. Albuquerque even abolished sati but didn't force mass conversions.

comprehensive.question: Analyze the Bahadur Shah incident (1534-1537): How does this episode exemplify Portuguese diplomatic-military opportunism? What precedent did it set for later European powers?
comprehensive.answer: Background: Humayun invaded Gujarat (1534), threatening Bahadur Shah's throne. Desperate, Bahadur sought Portuguese naval support. Portuguese Terms: Demanded Bassein and Diu - key ports - in exchange for military help. Bahadur agreed, needing immediate relief.

comprehensive.question: Compare the Portuguese approach to establishing maritime dominance (Cartaz system and Blue Water Policy) with traditional Asian trade patterns. Why was this revolutionary and how did it impact Asian economies?
comprehensive.answer: Traditional Asian Trade (pre-Portuguese): Open-access system operated for centuries. Multiple ports competed, traders chose routes freely. Local rulers taxed trade but didn't monopolize or require universal permits. Arab, Indian, Chinese, Southeast Asian merchants operated independently.

comprehensive.question: Evaluate the strategic importance of Goa as Portuguese headquarters (1510-1961). Why did it remain Portuguese for 451 years while other territories were lost earlier?
comprehensive.answer: Strategic Advantages: Central west coast location between northern (Gujarat) and southern (Malabar) trading zones. Excellent natural deep-water harbor for large Portuguese ships. Defensible - surrounded by water on three sides, easier to fortify than Cochin or Calicut.

comprehensive.question: Trace the evolution of Portuguese-Mughal relations from Akbar's reign through Shah Jahan's. What factors transformed cooperation into hostility?
comprehensive.answer: Akbar Era (1556-1605) - Cooperation: Akbar received Portuguese Jesuits (1580, 1591, 1595) at court, engaged in theological discussions. Portuguese traded freely in Mughal territories.

comprehensive.question: Assess the agricultural impact of Portuguese-introduced crops (tobacco, cashew, papaya, pineapple, guava). How did these New World crops transform Indian agriculture and economy?
comprehensive.answer: Crops Introduced: Tobacco and Cashew (Albuquerque era, early 1500s). Papaya, Pineapple, Guava (16th-17th centuries) [UPSC 2025]. These were New World (Americas) crops Portuguese transferred to Asia as part of Columbian Exchange.

comprehensive.question: Why did Portuguese power decline after 1600 while maintaining Goa until 1961? Analyze the paradox of simultaneously declining and persisting.
comprehensive.answer: Peak Period (1510-1600): Portuguese dominated Indian Ocean trade. Monopoly on spice routes to Europe. Network of bases from Mozambique to Malacca to Macau. Cartaz system forced most ships to pay Portuguese license fees. No European competitors in Asia. Military superiority unchallenged.
